title: Part A: Thesis
stimulusHtml:
A thesis statement expresses a defensible interpretation of a text.

The thesis may be more than one sentence.

For a thesis to be defensible, the passage must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn this point.

A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that interpretation.

In this task, students are asked to generate a defensible thesis about the passage and to locate evidence for it in the text. Then, they are to compose a paragraph in support of that thesis and include at least one piece of evidence from the text.

By the end of Unit 3, students should be able to demonstrate some understanding of skills related to literary analysis. This partial task is designed to offer an opportunity to practice such analysis in writing.
descriptions: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
Responds to the prompt with a thesis that presents a defensible interpretation of the passage.

title: Part B: Evidence and Commentary
stimulusHtml:
Commentary establishes and explains relationships among the evidence, reasoning, and thesis.

In Unit 3, students examine how conflict, or tension between competing values, functions in a text; this preparation should be useful to students as they approach this task. At this point in the course, students are likely still developing the skills involved in explaining the relationships among evidence, reasoning, and claims; thus, students may only earn up to 2 points in this row. Students will be able to earn up to 4 points in this row when they write full essays in later units.
